medium_description_en: Stages melanoma based on tumor, lymph nodes, and metastases.
instructions_en: This calculator is based on the 7th edition of the AJCC Cancer Staging Manual. The 8th edition is now recommended for use over this version.

seo.meta_description_en: TNM Staging for Melanoma stages melanoma based on tumor depth, lymph node involvement, and metastasis characteristics.
seo.keywords_en: Tnm, melanoma, skin cancer staging, abcd, abcde, 7 point checklist, malignant melanoma

how_to_use.use_case_en: Patients with confirmed melanoma diagnosed by biopsy.
how_to_use.pearls_pitfalls_en:
• Requires pathologic specimen for evaluation, so lymph node status cannot be adequately assessed until after surgical resection.
  • TNM staging is frequently updated based on new evidence. The AJCC 8th edition is expected to be implemented into clinical practice on January 1, 2018. Until then, all tumors should be staged according to the 7th edition.
how_to_use.why_use_en: TNM staging is the standard staging system used by surgeons, medical oncologists, and dermatologists to prognosticate and communicate about patients.

next_steps.advice_en: National Comprehensive Cancer Network (NCCN) guidelines use TNM staging for biopsy-confirmed cases of melanoma.
next_steps.management_en: All patients with biopsy-confirmed melanoma should be referred to a surgeon and/or medical oncologist.
next_steps.critical_actions_en:
• Per NCCN guidelines, when the sentinel lymph node is positive, complete lymph node dissection should be discussed.
    • When the sentinel lymph node is positive by pathology only, systemic imaging is indicated to evaluate specific signs or symptoms.
    • When the sentinel lymph node is clinically positive, systemic imaging should be performed for baseline staging.

3. Clinical staging includes microstaging of the primary melanoma and clinical/radiologic evaluation for metastases. By convention, it should be used after complete excision of the primary melanoma with clinical assessment for regional and distant metastases.

4. Pathologic staging includes microstaging of the primary melanoma and pathologic information about the regional lymph nodes after partial or complete lymphadenectomy. Pathologic Stage 0 or Stage IA patients are the exception; they do not require pathologic evaluation of their lymph nodes.

Original/Primary Reference.text: Edge SB, Byrd DR, Compton CC, Fritz AG, Greene FL, Trotti A, et al. Melanoma of the skin. AJCC Cancer Staging Manual. 7th ed. New York, NY: Springer-Verlag; 2010.

Clinical Practice Guidelines.text: NCCN Clinical Practice Guidelines in Oncology: Melanoma. V.1. 2017.

creator_info.about_en: Daniel G. Coit, MD, FACS, is a surgical oncologist at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. He is also a co-leader of the Melanoma Disease Management Team. Dr. Coit’s research interests include identifying high risk patients for melanoma recurrence and gastric cancer.
